results.title: Paper trail: the life & times of a woodchip
results.creator_credit: Sharon Connolly, Yarra Bank Films, ABC-TV (Australia), Film Victoria and Trevor Graham
results.brief_description: This program examines the devastating environmental effects of the Jappanese paper industry from the woodchipping of Australian forests to the problem of toxic waste produced by Japanese paper mills. Discusses the traditional environmental-safe way of paper making, the attitude to recycling programs in Japan, and the Japanese overuse of paper. If paper use trebles in the next decade, as predicted, Australia being a major supplier of woodchips to Japan, is in danger of losing its forests.

results.title: Paper plates to silver spoons: the complete guide to table manners
results.brief_description: Designed as a quick guide to table manners, this American production will amuse and inform. Table manners, utensil use, correct posture and table settings are discussed for both formal and informal dining situations. Cultural differences in table manners are also discussed. After watching this, viewers will be able to handle any dining situation with confidence as well as learning when it is acceptable to put elbows on the table and eat with one’s fingers!

results.title: Paper making
results.creator_credit: Sheridan Stumm, John Dobis and Discovery Video
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Tonia Todman’s craft room”.
Tonia Todman demonstrates how to make paper. She describes how to create interesting effects through the addition of grasses, seeds, flowers, and threads to your paper pulp. How to emboss or add a watermark to your paper is also explained. As well as recycling scrap paper, Tonia demonstrates how to produce paper from leaves and other natural products, and also from rags.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Sheridan Stumm, John Dobis and Discovery Video

results.title: Paper engineering
results.creator_credit: Adam Hart-Davis, Colin Nobbs and Yorkshire Television
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Mathematical eye”.
This program provides an introduction to geometry. It includes useful demonstrations showing how manufacturers use geometric principles to design packaging and how a variety of geometric shapes can be made by folding paper. The distinction is made between two and three dimensional shapes and the mathematical link between geometric shapes is explored.

results.title: Paper chain
results.brief_description: Shows the entire processes involved in the production of quality paper at one of Wiggins Teape many paper mills. Three types of raw material, old rags, wood pulp, and esparto grass are used. Shows special treatment for special types of paper and the innumerable uses of paper in all walks of life, and the extraordinary situation which would exist without paper.

results.title: Paper boy
results.creator_credit: Tom Daly, ONF | NFB and Clay Borris
results.brief_description: A film study of a newspaper boy in the crowded inner city, which provides substance for discussion of the city environment which can breed cynicism and delinquency in the young. Apartment buildings, rooming houses and dilapidated dwellings are the boy’s route, and his world a rundown flat and a rough spoken father. At some doors he tosses his papers with neat precision, at others will deliberate carelessness. Behind his actions you sense his resentment and anger, and at the same time a reaching out for warmth.

results.title: Papa, les Petits Bateaux = Papa the Little Boats
results.brief_description:
Venus de Palma (also known as Cookie) is a tough, sweet little rich girl, and is rather smart, too. She is smart enough and charming enough to outwit her kidnappers by setting one against the other until they have all killed each other or died trying to prove their worth to her. Kaplan was a journalist and assistant to Abel Gance before starting to make her own films, including several shorts on painters. She has also written surrealist/erotic novels under the name of Belen, and worked for television. Her claim to fame is her firts feature ‘La fiancee du pirate/Dirty Mary’ (1969), a key film in early femisnist film debates. (…) Kaplan subsequent films have been less successful, perhaps because her libertarian sensitivity became outmoded, but they have been consistently interesting if not controversial: for instance ‘Nea’ (1976), an attempt at soft porn from a woman’s point of view, and ‘Plaisir d’amour’ (1991), a tale of three women (grandmother, mother and daughter) who exhaust a man sexually.’ Reference: Ginette Vincendeau. ‘The companion to French cinema’. London: BFI Publishing, 1996

Credits: Director, Nelly Kaplan ; writers, Nelly Kaplan, Claude Makovski, Rene Guyonnet ; photography, Ricardo Aronovich ; music, Andre Popp.
Cast: Sheila White, Michel Bouquet, Judith Magre, Jean Paredes, Sydney Chaplin, Michel Lonsdale, Pierre Mondy, Catherine Allegret.

results.title: Pantomime - Fairy Tale Theatre
results.brief_description: This program takes a look at the magical world of pantomime, both on the stage and behind it, and meets some of the artists who have made panto their life’s work.

results.title: Panorama: cancer
results.brief_description: Discusses the nature of cancer, the facts which research has revealed and stresses the need to intensify clinical research. Prevention is important and must be publicised particularly the need to reduce smoking. Suggests forming a central international clearing house for data on cancer to speed its control.
